item.title: Introduction to Low-Level Design (LLD)
item.description:
1. What is Low-Level Design (LLD)?

Low-Level Design (LLD) refers to the detailed internal design of software components. It takes the high-level components defined during High-Level Design (HLD) and breaks them down into:

  • Classes and Interfaces
  • Relationships and Dependencies
  • Method Signatures and Data Flow

The focus of LLD is to create modular, scalable, and maintainable software, often represented via UML diagrams and object-oriented design principles.

üìù Key Point: LLD is where your abstract idea turns into actual implementation-ready building blocks.

item.title: SOLID Principles Overview
item.description:
1. SOLID Principles: The Foundation of Maintainable Software Design

Software design is not just about writing code; it’s about writing maintainable, scalable, and robust code. The SOLID principles, introduced by Robert C. Martin (Uncle Bob), provide a strong foundation for designing well-structured, extensible, and modular software. These principles help in reducing code smells, avoiding tight coupling, and improving code reusability.

  • S : Single Responsibility Principle
  • O : Open-Close Principle
  • L : Liskov Substitution Principle
  • I : Interface Segregation Principle
  • D : Dependency Inversion Principle

Let’s explore each principle with real-world examples and understand how they contribute to software quality.
